contact_us.feedback_message: How can I get the item delivered for Christmas?

panels.label: Question title summary line 1
panels.content: Icons are everywhere. These little miracle workers as John Hicks described them) help us reinforce meaning in the interfaces we design and build. Their popularity in web design has never been greater; the conciseness and versatility of pictograms in particular make them a lovely fit for displays large and small. But icons on the web have had their fair share of challenges. Icons are everywhere. These little miracle workers as John Hicks described them) help us reinforce meaning in the interfaces we design and build. panels.label: Question title summary line 2
panels.content: Most assistive devices will read aloud text inserted via CSS, and many of the Unicode characters icon fonts depend on are no exception. Best-case scenario, your favorite icon gets read aloud as black favorite star.

panels.label: Question title summary line 3
panels.content: When your icon font fails, the browser treats it like any other font and replaces it with a fallback. Best-case scenario, you have chosen your fallback characters carefully and something weird-looking but communicative still loads. Worse-case scenario and far more often, the user sees something completely incongruous, usually the dreaded missing character glyph.

panels.label: Question title summary line 4
panels.content: Many dyslexic people find it helpful to swap out a website typeface for something like OpenDyslexic. But icon fonts get replaced as well, which makes for a frustratingly broken experience.

panels.label: Question title summary line 5
panels.content: SVG is awesome for icons! It is a vector image format with optional support for CSS, JavaScript, reusability, accessibility and a bunch more. It was made for this sort of thing.
